items.title: Might Trump approve an Israeli annexation of the West Bank, or force Netanyahu to curb settlements?
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Illegal Israeli settlement activity has forcibly expelled many Palestinians from their homes. Far-right members of the Israeli government, including Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich and National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir, are calling for an illegal annexation of the occupied West Bank. Israel's governent is supporting the expansion of illegal Israeli settlements are expanding, and its far-right ministers are planning on taking over what's known as Area C in the West Bank. Whether President-elect Trump will impose limitations on this illegal activity or greenlight Israel's annexation of the occupied West Bank remains to be seen. 

Chapter Breakdown
0:00 8 Palestinians killed in Israeli raids
00:55 DW Correspondent Emily Gordine reports on illegal Israeli settlement activity in Khan al-Ahmar, West Bank, which is home to a Palestinian bedouin community
4.33 Ksenia Svetlova, Director of Israel Middle East Relations Program at Mitvim, and former Knesset Member, on how Trump might change or support illegal Israeli settlement activity in the West Bank
9:09 Akiva Eldar, Political analyst an Haaretz contributor, on Israeli government support for illegal settlements in the occupied West Bank
13:47 Laura Blumenfeld, Middle East Analyst and Senior Fellow at Johns Hopkins University, on whether Presidnet-elect Trump will greenlight annexation in the West Bank or push forward with "normalization" agreements


Note: One guest makes a reference to the possibility of a future apartheid regime under Israel -- the term "apartheid" in this context is highly disputed. Various human rights groups have made this allegation, but Israeli officials have repeatedly rejected it.

#israel #westbankannexation
#israelisettlements

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: Plane crash: What do we know so far about jet re-routing and crashing in Kazakhstan? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Authorities are investigating what caused an Azerbaijani Airlines passenger jet to crash in Kazakhstan, killing at least 38 people. The plane was supposed to travel a very different route from Azerbaijan's capital Baku to Grozny in Russia. Yet it flew off-course across the Caspian Sea and circled in the air over Aktau, Kazakhstan, before eventually crashing there. Remarkably,  more than two-dozen people on board survived.

Chapter Breakdown
0:00 Investigation underway into plane crash
1:58 Bakhyt Toptayeva, Journalist in Astana, on Kazakhstan authorities' investigation
4:35 Richard Levy, Aviation consultant, on possible factors causing plane to re-route and crash
9:14 Stephen Wright, Head of Aviation and Transport at the Technological University Dublin, on why the plane's black box will shed light on the crash


#kazakhstanplanecrash
#azerbaijaniairlines
#planecrash

items.author: DW News
items.content:

items.title: At least 8 Palestinians killed in what Israel says was counter-terrorism operation | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
At least eight Palestinians have been killed during raids by Israeli forces in the occupied West Bank. The troops raided refugee camps in the city of Tulkarm and in nearby Nur Shams. Israel says it was carrying out a counter-terrorism operation. Hamas says two members of its armed wing were killed. Hundreds of Palestinians and dozens of Israelis have been killed in the occupied West Bank since Hamas' terror attacks on Israel in October last year.

Chapters:
0:00 Palestinians killed
0:34 Balig Sladeen, Journalist

items.author: DW News
items.content:
The northeastern city of Kharkiv is among the hardest hit, with at least six injured. President Zelenskyy called the Christmas day attacks "inhuman". In Kyiv, families fled to the metro for shelter. Ukraine's air defence says it downed 59 of the incoming missiles targeting energy infrastructure.

items.title: Passenger jet crash in Kazakhstan kills dozens, rescue efforts underway | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Rescue efforts are underway at the site of a plane crash near the city of Aktau in Kazakhstan. The transport ministry says a total of 67 passengers and crew were on board the Azerbaijan Airlines flight. The number of reported survivors continues to vary. 

A video verified by AP news agency appears to show the moment the plane crashed. It was en route from Azerbaijan's capital Baku to the Russian city of Grozny. 
_
00:00 Survivors reported after plane crash in Kazakhstan 
00:53 Bakhyt Toptayeva, 24KZ Correspondent in Kazakhstan's capital Astana
03:40 Stephen Wright, Aviation Expert at the Technological University of Dublin

items.title: Can Ukraine protect its energy grid using aid in third winter of war? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Authorities in Ukraine are reporting a massive Russian aerial attack across the country. The northeastern city of Kharkiv is among the hardest hit, with at least six injured. The strikes are targeting the country's energy networks, which have led to regular power black-outs.  

Ukraine is now in its third winter of war. DW correspondent Max Zander reports from the capital Kyiv on how communities are coping with the hardship and disruption to daily life. 

00:00 Ukraine reports massive Russian missile attack  
03:15 Mikhail Krutikhin, Independent energy analyst 
06:10 Suriya Jayanti, Senior fellow at The Atlantic Council 
Suria Jayanti is a leading expert on energy policy and has worked extensively with Ukraine’s energy sector, both before and during the war.

items.title: Syria post-Assad: New leader dissolves rebel factions | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Syria's new administration says some of the rival rebel factions have agreed to disband and merge into a single force. 

The country's de-facto leader Ahmed al-Sharaa has reached an understanding with faction chiefs to dissolve their groups and unite under the defense ministry. The interim prime minister Mohammed al-Bashir says the ministry will be restructured to include former rebels and officers from the army of the ousted dictator Bashar al-Assad. One major group has held out from disarming so far - the Kurdish-led Syrian Defense Forces, and their People's Protection Units, also known as the YPG. 

Giorgio Cafiero further explains the deal. He is a Middle East Analyst and CEO and founder of Gulf State Analytics, a geopolitical risk consultancy based in Washington DC.

00:00 Syrian rebel groups agree to merge, but not all 
00:55 Giorgio Cafiero, Gulf State Analyst

#Syria #Assad #Sharaa #Bashir #Kurdistan 
For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: Bangladesh requests extradition of ousted Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina from India | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Bangladesh has sent a formal request to India to extradite the ousted prime minister Sheikh Hasina. She fled to Delhi in August after a student-led uprising ended her 15-year rule.  Hasina faces charges of crimes against humanity, as well as charges stemming from the deaths of hundreds of protesters during the uprising last summer. 

DW's Beenish Javed reports on Bangladesh's interim government wanting Sheikh Hasina extradited back from India.

#sheikhhasina #bangladeshprotest #bangladeshindia

items.title: NASA Parker Solar Probe makes history in attempting closest-ever approach to sun | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
NASA's Parker Solar Probe is making history by flying closer to the sun than any human made object in history. The solar probe was due to zip past the sun for a flyby on Christmas Eve, traveling at more than 430,000 miles per hour. This NASA spacecraft is the fastest human-made object ever. Scientists hope the mission to the sun will help us deepen our understanding of the star.

Chapter Breakdown
0:00 Solar probe fastest-ever object made by humans
2:13 Keith Cowing, Editor at NASAWATCH.com, on how close the NASA solar probe will attempt to get to the sun

items.title: Justice for Darayya massacre victims: Will Syria’s new leadership hold Assad to account? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
In the Damascus suburb of Darayya, eyewitnesses of a massacre carried out by Assad’s forces and his proxies in 2012 are now breaking their silence. With some members of Bashar al-Assad’s regime still in government positions, will Syria’s new rebel leadership seek to hold Assad, now in Russia, and other members of his former regime, accountable for rights abuses?
 
DW speaks to Alan Haji, Team Lead at the Syrian Justice and Accountability Centre in the Hague

To watch report discussed in interview, click here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iMMKC-X51ys
